zuul/scheduler.py.message:
This will also retry successful builds if they return retry for some reason. It's probably up to debate if we should allow this or if we only should allow to retry failed builds. I'd vote for only retrying failed builds.

Further this doesn't take job.attempts into account so we're running into the risk of endless loops due to job misbehavior. So I think we should limit the retries to job.attempts just like we do with the existing retry_limit handling.

> This will also retry successful builds if they return retry for some reason. It's probably up to debate if we should allow this or if we only should allow to retry failed builds. I'd vote for only retrying failed builds.

I don't have a strong opinion either way, so I'll remove it.

> Further this doesn't take job.attempts into account so we're running into the risk of endless loops due to job misbehavior. So I think we should limit the retries to job.attempts just like we do with the existing retry_limit handling.

I think it does actually. This only retries if 'result is None' and the executor sets the result to 'RETRY_LIMIT' if all attempts are exhausted.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: LGTM - I actually learned a lot from this one.

This's the initial draft of firstboot yaml file,
Please review it, and I'm going to run a full deployment with it to make sure everything is OK

Is this for backport to some old release? These firstboot configurations can't be used since wallaby with novaless node provisioning. Instead you should be using config-drive[1].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/provisioning/baremetal_provision.html#config-drive
It's going to be backported to queens for rhel-osp 6.2

I don't think this will work with any version of TripleO using Ephemeral Heat, since Heat isn't used to provision the nodes and thus can't provide userdata.

So, if the intention is to include this in anything > W, then I don't believe this is the right approach:
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/wallaby/ephemeral-heat-overcloud.html

Refer to the link mentioned by tkajinam for how to use userdata in version > W using the new node provision process.

Note that NodeUserData no longer works in master and wallaby, since heat and nova are no longer involved in baremetal node provisioning.
If you intend to make this work in these branches they this should be re-implemented by a new method.
 https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/provisioning/baremetal_provision.html#config-drive
We already discussed about it not being relevant from wallaby+ in patchset2 (check earlier comments). Let's merge this and leave it for them to work out the approach for master/wallaby later.

Assuming this is something that need to happen before applying network configuration with os-net-config an alternative to config-drive is to use the playbook interface. See kernel args example.

Can you expand on the use case here? We decided after our experiments with puppet that our system-config is not really intended for external re-consumption. The effort required is significant and we weren't getting enough assistance to make it viable. Instead if you want to do this you should have your own docker-compose files and roles.

We have deployed the same architecture of infra system in our company for code development about more than 8 years, tracked with upstream of OpenInfra, from zuul v2 (jenkins + puppet) to zuul v3 (ansible + puppet + zuul), now managed by zuul with docker-compose.

The fact is in the internal production environment, we can't catch up with the new changes as quick as possible, because of some new version of the components are incompatible with the version that we use, and also we need to find maintenance time windows to upgrade, to put it another way, it will be much more friendly for us that we can pin "stable" version in production use.

For me about the internal maintenance work, the most ansible roles of system-config is good enough to use and can also to keep up with the new changes, except the tag in docker-compose file. So the purpose of this patch is to make image tags are configurable, so we can use ansible vars to control the upgrade work manually at the suitable time, other than the latest version.
Uses same pattern for determining OS as fm does

cleanup-dataplane.yml L66:
```
    # cleanup Neutron ml2/ovs namespaces
    for netns in $(ip netns | awk '/^(snat|fip|qdhcp|qrouter)-/{ print $1 }'); do
        echo "Cleaning up namespace $netns"
        ip netns delete $netns
    done

```
With this patch we are avoiding to duplicate the sg-/fg- interfaces during the clone-br-int.sh. And at this point since the system is already configured with OVN those interfaces are not used anymore (since the snat/fip is done by the openflow)

ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/connection.py.message:
Just asking: if I'm not wrong, this is fixing the existing behaviour (that was not working).

Is L232-235 what is (also) needed to fix this patch.

Both are required to fix. With just lines 232-234 I noticed that Neutron would hang at start and not answer API requests. I *think* this is because the newer OVS ConditionState tracks condition change state and just overwriting it can break that state machine. I haven't tracked down exactly why that is happening, just that it specifically happened when modifying existing table entries in this code.

I think we should also modify the neutron code that calls update_tables to not do so in the case that the specified tables are already in our schema. But it seems like protecting against that here as well makes sense.
I think it would be good to get this unittested

I modified the existing functional test so that it verifies that the Idl is still functional after updating the tables, and verified that it fails before the patch exactly as the bug report showed and it passes with this patch.

As discussed on IRC, I couldn't really think of a unit test that would be more useful than just verifying that the code actually works with the functional test. I admit that my bias against them when dealing with python-ovs code might make me bad at coming up with useful tests, though.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: This sounds to me like the filter of changed/reverted files is not 100% correct. E.g. given a file X that was changed and the change reverted in the same PR could still show up as change when the target branch diverged in a way that also affected file X.

ansible/roles/apt/defaults/main.yml.message: why not /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d/ ? which is still recommended in man-page http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/jammy/man8/apt-key.8.html

Because of use apt_key module here https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blob/fa2a0d572bd195a56e3843e024ac1fdada8e1764/ansible/roles/baremetal/tasks/pre-install.yml#L100-L105 without defining proxy we can put docker repo key to apt_keys variable in ansible/roles/apt/defaults/main.yml
but also we will need change apt_keys_path to default Ubuntu /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d or installation will fail. Otherwise ansible apt_key module(and system apt-key util) will not see predefined docker repo key and fails installation because of trying to download this key without proxy.

Or we need to change kolla-ansible code to smth like:
```
- name: Install docker apt gpg key
  environment:
    http_proxy: "{{ apt_proxy_http | default('', true) }}"
    https_proxy: "{{ apt_proxy_https | default('' ,true) }}"
  apt_key:
    url: "{{ docker_apt_url }}/{{ docker_apt_key_file }}"
    id: "{{ docker_apt_key_id }}"
```
and pass apt_proxy_http* variables from kayobe in ansible/roles/kolla-ansible/templates/globals.yml.j2
with smth like:
```
{% if apt_proxy_http is defined %}
   apt_proxy_http: "{{ apt_proxy_http }}"
{% endif %}
{% if apt_proxy_https is defined %}
   apt_proxy_https: "{{ apt_proxy_https }}"
{% endif %}
```
But in this case apt_key module anyway put its key to default Ubuntu directory

> As I mentioned, apt_key is no longer recommended, and several sources point out that the new /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d location is not ideal, since those keys become trusted for all repositories.
> 
> Instead, in this approach we trust a specific key for each repository.

ok, but we support only Ubuntu for now!? and also the unoficial blog for Debian says '/usr/share/keyrings' (which exist and provided by the ubuntu-keyring package) not '/usr/local/share/keyrings/ as in your patch.

> As for the proxy issue, I suggest either fixing it in kolla-ansible, or setting enable_docker_repo to false and defining it in kayobe.

indeed. nice catch!

/usr/share and /usr/local/share have a similar purpose, but this (and wikipedia) suggest /usr/local/share might be more appropriate here.

https://askubuntu.com/questions/1150090/usr-share-vs-usr-local-share-where-to-install-ca-certs
Putting keys there makes them trusted by all repos, whereas this location is not trusted by default. See e.g. https://www.linuxuprising.com/2021/01/apt-key-is-deprecated-how-to-add.html

As I mentioned, apt_key is no longer recommended, and several sources point out that the new /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d location is not ideal, since those keys become trusted for all repositories.

Instead, in this approach we trust a specific key for each repository.

As for the proxy issue, I suggest either fixing it in kolla-ansible, or setting enable_docker_repo to false and defining it in kayobe.
and why we don't support defaults? BTW we support only Ubuntu in the Debian world: https://docs.openstack.org/kayobe/latest/support-matrix.html

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
> Patch Set 4:
> 
> The gauge certainly complicates things.
> 
> I think we could go with the do-it-in-zuul approach, but we can simplify that a little:
> 
> The zuul_system_id is stored in ZK as NodeRequest.requestor (i.e., it's already a top level attribute on the node request).  We can have nodepool copy that over to the Node as a new field Node.request, and then have Zuul check that.
> 
> That way we get the system id as a top level variable automatically propagated from node requests in a generic way.

Updated accordingly. The accompanying change in nodepool is here https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/nodepool/+/834109.

zuul/nodepool.py.message: This is not necessary -- Zuul 4.10.0 requires Nodepool 4.3.0 where this was added.

This part of the change is troubling.  It intentionally includes nodes which do not belong to this zuul, in order to count them and emit a stat called "zuul.nodepool.resources".  It's starting to seem like this should be a change to Nodepool instead of Zuul.

Why not keep the zuul_system filter which would make this "nodepool resources allocated to this zuul tenant",  or, move this to nodepool which would then be "nodepool resources allocated to this nodepool tenant"?

I thought about this as well.

Still filtering for the zuul_system_id in its current form would not work, as this is stored in node.user_data. We have this only for in-use, used, and held nodes. For the new metric, we especially want to include ready nodes. So we'd need to set the zuul_system_id on a separate property, also already on the node requests like we do with the tenant_name. This would require an accompanying change in nodepool.

Generally, I also have the feeling that it would be nicer to have this metric entirely implemented in nodepool. But there we would have the "problem" that we can't easily zero the gauges because we don't know the set of all tenants.

So as the latter option (nodepool-side impl.) is probably not acceptable because of inaccurate metrics, I'd go with the former and add another "zuul_system_id" property to NodeRequest and Node (and removing the system_id from the user_data).

What do you think? Any other options I overlooked?

This seems inconsistent with our root image, where we set net.ifnames=1.

The default of eth0 is unlikely to be correct on a typical system with multiple interfaces, even after this change.

It is inconsistent but it is a different use case:

- for root disk image, we want consistent naming (via systemd or maybe via biosdevname) to make sure we identify and configure correctly each interface. Provisioning configures the provisioning network interface based on MAC address, so we don't need to know its naming in advance. We can connect to the host and discover its interfaces before executing host configuration.

- for the IPA image, we want to gather the hostname from LLDP, which may be set on multiple interfaces. If eth0 is not working, it is easy to add rules for eth1, eth2, etc. Keeping the current approach requires discovering interface names before setting introspection rules, which is cumbersome.

cinder/tests/fixtures.py.message: Is the "[:]" necessary?  Not sure if I'm missing a detail here...

I'm pretty sure there was a reason for this but I'm disappointed that I never left a comment explaining this when I first wrote it (for nova). This does a different things to "normal" assignment, as you most likely know [1], and warnings is a global so I suspect that's the reason for it. I'd need to test to be sure though.

Later: aha, it's what cpython does [2]. That was likely it. I won't lie, I didn't really explore (and still haven't explored) whether this was necessary, but it also was no harm so maybe good enough (or at least follow-up territory)?

[1]

  >>> a = [1, 2, 3]
  >>> b = a
  >>> a = [0]
  >>> a
  [0]
  >>> b
  [1, 2, 3]

  >>> a = [1, 2, 3]
  >>> b = a
  >>> a[:] = [0]
  >>> a
  [0]
  >>> b
  [0]

[2] https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/5498a61c7c25db6f9e76032aa9c5153d79e09889/Lib/test/support/warnings_helper.py#L183-L189

I think only this needs to be performed here, the rest can be handled using dh mechanisms

Add a new file nfs-utils-config/source-debian/systemd/00-nfs-utils-config.preset, containing:

 disable rpc-statd.service
 disable rpc-statd-notify.service
 enable nfs-common.service
 enable nfs-server.service

The presets will enable/disable the services

I tested this approach including the 00-nfs-utils-config.preset override under /etc/systemd/system and the enable of nfs-common and it remained loaded/inactive. The only way I could make it work was via unmask/enable of the service in the postinst:

sysadmin@localhost:~$ systemctl status nfs-common
● nfs-common.service
     Loaded: masked (Reason: Unit nfs-common.service is masked.)
     Active: inactive (dead)
sysadmin@localhost:~$ cat /etc/systemd/system-preset/00-nfs-utils-config.preset                                                 
disable rpc-statd.service 
disable rpc-statd-notify.service
enable nfs-common.service
enable nfs-server.service
sysadmin@localhost:~$

So, my suggestion here is to remain at least the nfs-common on the postinst, because the unmask seems necessary at postinst.

I saw the disable for the rpc ones on preset already, but I decided to keep here just in case. I tried enabling the nfs-common just with the preset file and it didn't work, I could not even do it manually by unmasking directly. For the nfs-server it is there already.

Any idea how this behaves on an install w/ an existing bridge set to None? Will the task change that to Standalone or break? Also, I believe not specifying network_interface in the provider block will skip this task entirely
The answer is.. when fail_mode is explicit None, you can change it to standalone or secure (back and forth) without issue. Once defined, you can't set to None. LGTM, thanks!

According to man ovs-vswitchd.conf.db: 

The default is standalone if the value is unset, but future versions of Open vSwitch may change the default.

So it should be safe on existing bridge, where fail_mode isn't set, albeit, it would be changed to explicit standalone. 

There is separate action to clear previously set fail_mode: ovs-vsctl del-fail-mode <bridge>, but no counterpart for it in openvswitch_bridge module.

So, to summarize: prior to this change, if fail_mode was explicitly set to any value, this task would fail. With this change, it would set fail_mode to explicit standalone.
other than the pep8 (extra import) leftover, it looks good to me

I need to look more into it but, I don't think we should remove this task method because, even tho the Logical Switches are created or updated accordingly with the IGMP configuration option this maintenance task still covers the case where the configuration option value is changed and the Neutron service is restarted without any updates to the Logical Switches. In this case this maintenance task will pick up on the new values of the IGMP configuration option and configure the LS accordingly

specs/xena/approved/prometheus-metrics-e.message:
The above is all quite Canonical centric - I think the main objective of this spec is to improve the observability of bind and haproxy across the OpenStack Charms.

As such I think we should make the above more generic - Prometheus is a popular tool for metrics gathering and we just need to detail we're enabling support for this in various parts of OpenStack.
Ack

Work covering the snap would typically be covered outside the scope of the Charm specification as this is about distribution of a software component.

That said I'd like to see the snap placed under team ownership with a clear route to making changes and automated publication - preferable owned by 'Canonical' as an assertion of worthiness and support ability.

You may also wish to consider whether the Debian packaged version of this project is sufficient - leveraging the community across Ubuntu and Debian to support it over the longer term.
The idea the Observability team be responsible for the maintenance of the snap. I will add this info in the spec.

General question - does this have scope outside of designate-bind?

In which case you may wish to consider this not being a part of the OpenStack Charms project (although there is specific impact on the designate-bind charm to support so a spec is still good!)

In theory it could have scope outside designate-bind, but I'm not aware if exists other charms that could benefit from this.

I'm considering this charm being outside the OpenStack Charms project and the ownership will be with DevOps Centres or Observability team. Will add this info in the spec.

I'd probably avoid allowing operators to set the port - this works 99% of the time until someone accidentally re-uses a port and either looses stats or some other critical network service.  Let the charm set this automatically - it can even check for existing use if need be but that's probably over-engineering the solution.

Likewise on the stats groups - its fine to be opinionated about best practices!
Ack
I'd really hoped we might move away from this very loosely typed interface for the new LMA charms.

While "http" implies no intent, the endpoint name does. In this case, the prometheus-bind-exporter charm defines "bind-exporter" as endpoint. Such endpoint runs on a HTTP server with support for the "/metrics" URI.

Getting rid of the "http" interface on this charm (who would not be owned by the OpenStack team) would affect charm-prometheus2 and many other exporter charms that relate with charm-prometheus2 through this interface.

The prometheus-operator charm [0] uses the prometheus_scrape interface, which is more purpose built and I think we should align on that. If the prometheus2 charm needs to be updated to support this interface (even a minimal subset for compatibility) I would think that would be the appropriate action to take.

[0] https://github.com/canonical/prometheus-operator/blob/main/metadata.yaml
The interaction with the interface will be pretty much to provide hostname and port. We considered that it was a good idea utilize what is already implemented. Do you have a suggestion for this?
Alvaro - yes, that's the approach I'd like to move down at the current time.

Billy could you confirm this is the approach we should take for the OpenStack charms? Implement the "prometheus_scrape" interface to add native compatibility with Canonical Observability Stack (COS).

Previous support of the "http" interface in some charms may be discussed at a later stage, but for new developments, we should enable "prometheus_scrape".

For client charms (others than the ones part of COS), we should aim to support "prometheus_scrape". This aligns with "Approach 2" in the spec created by James P.

'http' implies no intent on the use of the interface - lots of things use 'http' for communication (so that's the how the relation will be implemented) but really the type of the interface is not http - its prometheus-endpoint or something else suitable strongly typed.
Localhost only access sounds good if we can't provide any type of authentication.
Ack

Again I'd just avoid doing this - it add complexity which is not really worth the cost IMHO.

127.0.0.1 and a fixed port avoid users doing insecure things.
Ack
This can be worked into the haproxy context helper in the openstack contrib module for classic charms and into charms.openstack for reactive charms.
Ack
+1 on use of the relation endpoint binding.
Ack
again - don't make this configurable - this can be provided by the charm and that's 100% fine and fits the don't allow the user to shoot themselves in the foot test.
Ack

why don't we use a resource for the dashboard that's part of the charmhub charm release definition? that way we don't have to produce a release of the charmhelpers library in order to update the dashboard.
That is a good idea and might give more flexibility to specific needs. Thanks for the suggestion.
-1 (see comments above)
Ack

specs/yoga/approved/prometheus-metrics-e.message: This is all still quite Canonical centric (old LMA stack, new LMA stack, etc)
I wonder if a whole new charm is better or if the prometheus exporter should just be included in the charm itself.
I think prometheus-bind-exporter is needed because bind metrics collection can happen on any environment (not only openstack [and designate-bind])

Hi Billy.

After talking with Alvaro we changed the sprec and now we are including the logic of prometheus-bind-exporter-operator inside designate-bind that will be responsible of installing the snap and configuring it.

Details of the snap are outside the scope of the charm and shouldn't be in the charm spec. This should be defined elsewhere and the scope of this spec should contain charm relevant information, i.e. the charm will use the snap and how the charm is expected to interact with the snap.

Per James' previous comment, we should use a more focused interface rather than the generic http interface.

The prometheus operator charm [0] requires a metrics-endpoint using the prometheus_scrape interface which is more purpose built. We should use that interface rather than the generic http interface.

[0] https://github.com/canonical/prometheus-operator

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I just bumped the limit to 100MiB which matches upstream in 1.0.0 (which is not included in the upper constraints for older releases of OpenStack that are still supported).
I'd like a small note indicating why we do this, but I'm okay doing that in a follow-up. Holding off on +W to make sure you see this 😊
Thanks for digging into this,  I have just some arguments against hardcoding a max_buff_size to oslo.privsep

oslo_privsep/comm.py.message:
default value [1] is 100M, you are reducing it to 8M (12.5 times less). Is that what you want?

[1]https://github.com/msgpack/msgpack-python/blob/bdf0511e29b02427437b03e7d8454bd5076e837f/msgpack/fallback.py#L291

Good catch, I did some more checking.  In this case, the `msgpack` version inside upper-constraints.txt for Ussuri is:

https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/stable/ussuri/upper-constraints.txt#L685

This does not include the increase of the limits which happened in 1.0.0

https://github.com/msgpack/msgpack-python/blob/main/ChangeLog.rst#100

This was only bumped inside Victoria:

https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/stable/victoria/upper-constraints.txt#L381

Should we bump upper-constraints to 1.0.0 or should be bump this to 100 to account for previous versions?  I'd like to hear your thoughts on this.

Can we get a small note here indicating why we configure things this way? It's possible that we'll want to drop it again in the future (where e.g. only msgpack >= 1.x is supported, or they change their default again)

This is already the default value [1]. Does the solution is not simply to pin msgpack to 1.0.0 [2] by default?

1.0.3 is already supported by upper-constraints [3].

[1] https://msgpack-python.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#msgpack.Unpacker
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.privsep/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L12
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/src/branch/master/upper-constraints.txt#L407

Unless there's a significant performance penalty for the larger buffer size (which seems unlikely since this is now the default in upstream msgpack), I think we should set this to a sufficiently large value and forget it. This is an implementation detail of privsep and should not be exposed to users, whether that's consuming projects or admins. It's a much better user experience if it Just Works(tm).

Just bumping the minimum requirement to 1.0.0 would also work, but this has the advantage of being backportable.

> Unless there's a significant performance penalty for the larger buffer size (which seems unlikely since this is now the default in upstream msgpack), I think we should set this to a sufficiently large value and forget it. 

Agreed

can't we have a config option for this? Thus giving the flexibility to the admin and keeping the size limited? Or isn't it possible to make buff_size a param for PrivContext, thus we can decide in the caller code to use the default buff_size or use a higher for linuxbridge for example?

pbr/version.py.message:
You can do the import like...

    # TODO: simplify this once Python 3.8 is the oldest we support

try:
        import importlib.metadata
        use_importlib = True
    except ModuleNotFoundError:
        import pkg_resources
        use_importlib = False

And then wrap the new code in checks for use_importlib with the old code in an else fallback block. Bonus points for moving all the metadata lookup code into isolated functions to better contain the split logic.

.pre-commit-config.yaml.message:
Hello,

Well, the version of flake8 to use here will be determined by the pulled version of hacking, here >=3.0.1,<3.1.0. So, here, hacking will pull flake8 <3.8.0,>=3.6.0 [1].

This is not the root cause of your problem. Something in your environment install an higher version of flake8 which break the pep8 tests, but this code is not the culprit concerning this bug.

The question is more why lot of your `requirements` are not aligned to what is supported by Wallaby.

For now I can't reproduce the issue locally. I created another patch to check this bug without this patch in our gates [2], let see what's happen with this patch.

You should notice that I'm not against upgrading hacking for the `master` branch, though I don't want to upgrade it on stable branch. Upgrading requirements is forbidden by our policy if it don't fix a bug, and it seems to not be the case here. Your bugzilla refer to wallaby, I don't think we will agree to backport this patch to that old stable branch, especially if this is not the root cause of the problem.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/tag/3.0.1/requirements.txt#L1
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.middleware/+/829508

My main concern with these downstream jobs, is that they are based on rhel8 even for OSP17 (wallaby) (`nodeset: pod-rhel-8`) [1]. OSP17 is on rhel9.

Also, as a side note, I noticed that bindep has been enabled for the pep8 [2] job all the time, I don't think we need it all the time, especially for pep8 in our case...

[1] https://code.engineering.redhat.com/gerrit/gitweb?p=openstack/osp-internal-jobs.git;a=blob;f=zuul.d/osp-tox-jobs.yaml;h=fae71a0640049f9cca5f6723da4513ed69c9dfe7;hb=refs/heads/master#l51
[2] https://code.engineering.redhat.com/gerrit/gitweb?p=openstack/osp-internal-jobs.git;a=commitdiff;h=d6e3dca1b42e4578d417d31e13049c6095135a57

@Stephen: Here are the downstream patch and its zuul logs who triggered this discussion.

https://code.engineering.redhat.com/gerrit/c/oslo.middleware/+/304286
https://sf.hosted.upshift.rdu2.redhat.com/zuul/t/osp-internal/build/50e5bdc2767346a886659253bbedf597/log/job-output.txt

If you read the logs then you can observe a weird behavior.

Indeed, in a first time tox is executed without tests [1] and tox install all the requirements, hacking and flake8 are installed in a compatible version [2], everything goes fine and this tox target exit 0 [3]. The requirements versions are identicals between pre-commit [4] and test-requirements [5].

[1] https://sf.hosted.upshift.rdu2.redhat.com/zuul/t/osp-internal/build/50e5bdc2767346a886659253bbedf597/log/job-output.txt#290
[2] https://sf.hosted.upshift.rdu2.redhat.com/zuul/t/osp-internal/build/50e5bdc2767346a886659253bbedf597/log/job-output.txt#781
[3] https://sf.hosted.upshift.rdu2.redhat.com/zuul/t/osp-internal/build/50e5bdc2767346a886659253bbedf597/log/job-output.txt#794
[4] https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.middleware/src/branch/stable/wallaby/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L35
[6] https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.middleware/src/branch/stable/wallaby/test-requirements.txt#L6

Then after this target another tox target is executed with tests, however, here it will fail to retrieve a compatible versions of flake8 and then this target will exit in error (the pep8 job will exit in error). 

[7] https://sf.hosted.upshift.rdu2.redhat.com/zuul/t/osp-internal/build/50e5bdc2767346a886659253bbedf597/log/job-output.txt#882
[8] https://sf.hosted.upshift.rdu2.redhat.com/zuul/t/osp-internal/build/50e5bdc2767346a886659253bbedf597/log/job-output.txt#1239
[9] https://sf.hosted.upshift.rdu2.redhat.com/zuul/t/osp-internal/build/50e5bdc2767346a886659253bbedf597/log/job-output.txt#1256

The same requirements file installed through tox don't lead to the same situation. Unfortunatelly I can't reproduce this problem locally, however, this problem appear at each zuul job running.

Stephen can take a look to these logs, maybe you'll see something that I missed.

This is an alternative to consider to other recent Rabbit patches. It need plenty of testing - I'm starting by checking that CI is happy. Any comments welcome.

A few observations from testing:

- Applying this patch removes the old ha-all policy from the definitions file, but it remains as a policy in RabbitMQ. The new, non-mirrored policy appears to override it, but since both policies have the same priority this is only by chance. At the very least the new policy should have the priority increased.
- With the new policy applied (zero replicas), randomly restarting a Rabbit instance can easily trigger an error loop of messages like this which doesn't go away:
    2022-01-24 16:49:30.460 [error] emulator Discarding message {'$gen_call',
    {<0.6577.0>,#Ref<0.457173882.3495690241.118155>},stat} from <0.6577.0> to <0.1311.0> in an old
    incarnation (2) of this node (3)
- The error loop can usually be stopped by restarting the nodes on which it isn't occurring.
- If RabbitMQ is deployed with no policies (by removing all state and re-deploying it), I have not been able to trigger the above error loop. I have tried switching between the two scenarios and it seems reproducible (so far). It isn't clear why. The amq* exchanges do not appear to be affected by switching between the exactly 1 policy and no-policy in the management GUI. Possibly they are at some other level.
- The most straight forward path to removing the HA policy is to re-deploy RabbitMQ after removing the volumes and containers. This is disruptive, but the alternative is likely to trigger the error loop, which is also disruptive.

Another related bug report / discussion on the error loop:
https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-server/discussions/2950#discussioncomment-581738
I like the direction, considering all the reading and writeup you have done. Thank you. Please find comments on small issues inline.

Just wanted to publicly state that I really like the approach Doug has found here.

It is supported by RabbitMQ upstream, we gain reliable (ish!) automatic failover when we loose a rabbit node. This seems loads better that my attempt to patch up the existing mirror queues approach, and the current status quo.
Thanks for the feedback. We should consider the TTL patch John proposed as well. I'll follow up on that next.

1. First job was an upgrade, which goes from ha-all to no mirroring.
2. In the Xena backport there is no change of policy by default.
We only down rmq on upgrades, so no wonder there are 0 such issues when we don't upgrade.

Well, then tell me why the same CI job run produces no errors on stable/xena? https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_47a/834298/1/check/kolla-ansible-centos8s-source-cephadm/47a5593/primary/logs/kolla/index.html

releasenotes/notes/gerrit-submit-whole-t.message: Even with a git dependency, all the changes in the topic should be submitted together.  So Zuul will see the entire topic as a dependency cycle (sort of superimposed on the git dependency tree), and I think that matches the Gerrit behavior and user expectation.

I guess with submitWholeTopic it is possible that the dependencies there are not circuluar (at least as expressed in git). Should we require that the gerrit side be expressed as a circular dependency to be in line with how zuul treats it? Less user friendly is the downside but more explicit in how it is treated.

zuul/driver/gerrit/gerritconnection.py.message:
Absolutely nothing: if submitWholeTopic is enabled for a gerrit site, and pipeline circular dependencies are not enabled, we will report errors to the user.  The errors should be self-explanatory.

I think this behavior is correct -- even though we don't produce an error today, Gerrit and Zuul have different expectations for what will happen when submit is pressed.  Now, if their expectations are different, then users will be aware of it.
This list will be empty when the submitWholeTopic option isn't enabled for changes. But what ensures that pipeline circular dependencies are enabled before processing this code?

After discussion on Matrix I think it might be helpful to have a comment above this line (1044) that reads something like:

  Gerrit changes marked to be submitted together do not necessarily get posted with dependency cycles using git trees and depends-on. However, they are functionally equivalent to stack of changes with cycles using those methods. Here we set needs_changes and needed_by_changes as if there were a cycle. This ensures Zuul's cycle handling manages the submit together changes properly.

The condition here is a restriction on the condition above. I think this means that we may add a change twice to the list/sets modified in these two blocks.

Is this second block necessary if we area always adding the dep even if it isn't the current patchset? Or maybe we only want to add the current patchset and can remove the first block?

The two blocks (I'm assuming you mean 1044-1046 and 1047-1050) modify different lists -- one is depends-on, the other is needed-by.  Each of the above seccions (ie, above line 1028) only handles one direction, but since we're always doing dependency cycles, we do both.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
1)Module is not configured to install packages at runtime -> we don't have a need for puppet-archive.



2)Seems if camptocamp-systemd is present rabbitmq changes behavior. Parsing the upstream commits.. it will set the service limitNOFILE to 16384 by default. On CentOS we have it 16384, on Debian 524288. This is in effect only before unlock. After unlock it becomes sm managed with a limit of 8192.


Debian before unlock now:
Max open files            1024                 524288               files   
CentOS before unlock:
Max open files            16384                16384                files    
sm-managed, both OSes:
Max open files            8192                 8192                 files    


I'm assuming we want to keep the same behavior as on CentOS so we want to add camptocamp-systemd.

Yet I don't see a big risk letting camptocamp-systemd uninstalled, thus file limit set to 524288 only for the duration bootstrap/restore/upgrade; this way we have one less package to build/maintain + only patch rabbit metadata.json to remove puppet-archive and camptocamp-systemd.

Is this just work in progress?  I just see yaml files added pointing to the source, but nothing in deb_folders for actually building it.  If it is just WIP you should mark it as such if this version of gerrit supports WIP.
Removing my approval until Al's issue gets addressed.

Here is an example of one.  Note its status in the upper left corner, is brown and says work in progress, not blue and active.
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/834004

Here's how to do it:
https://gerrit-review.googlesource.com/Documentation/intro-user.html#wip

This way it is clear that it is just a work in progress and not ready for review.  WF -1 just prevents the commit from going in, it doesn't mean not ready for review.  While a review is WIP, the REPLY button won't give us reviewers a way to WF it, so no danger of it accidentally going in.  And we won't get spammed with email on every further change you make to it while it is WIP.

All that said, it is possible that the WIP option isn't enabled on our STX repos though.  I don't use it myself, and can't recall if I've seen anyone use it on our STX repos.
Going back to the approach presented on patchset 1.
If you set WF -1 on any review you should state why in the REPLY message.  eg. Setting WF -1 while waiting for testing to finish, but please review.
